evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

The airport operator and ATC were notified. Soon after, representatives from the airport operator and the RFFS were on scene. The aircraft sustained substantial damage to the rear of the aircraft, including the APU, which was running at the time.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root

slot_statements.availability: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew was observed and documented in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_pair_engine_t2_interim phase on 12-25.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_pair_engine_t2_interim context is resistant to common defeaters, as evidence consistently supports the occurrence and impact of this breakdown.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features identified in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_pair_engine_t2_interim data, indicating a failure in effective crew interaction and coordination.

slot_statements.availability: The procedural deviation in pushback execution is observed and documented within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA aircraft during the 12-25 hist_pair_engine_t2_interim phase.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The procedural deviation in pushback execution demonstrates resistance to common defeaters and maintains validity within the context of the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_pair_engine_t2_interim scope.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The procedural deviation in pushback execution aligns with key features identified in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_pair_engine_t2_interim dataset, reflecting relevant operational characteristics.

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew was observed and documented in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_pair_engine_t2_interim phase on 12-25.

assumptions: Communication/coordination breakdown includes failure to warn or alert about impending collision
The lack of warning from wingman and headset operator constitutes a breakdown
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, timely communication and warnings preventing the incident
If procedural deviations rather than communication failures were primary cause

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.
He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1 and H2 show communication among crew and a decision to stop pushback, while H8 indicates lack of warning signals from wingman or headset operator, supporting documented communication/coordination breakdown.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Ambiguity in whether communication failure or procedural deviation was primary cause

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution is observed and documented within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA aircraft during the 12-25 hist_pair_engine_t2_interim phase.

assumptions: TRP ground markings were adequately visible and understood by the crew.
No mechanical or communication failures contributed to the incident.
defeaters: If evidence showed inadequate or unclear TRP markings or environmental factors causing confusion, this would favor environmental deficiency.
If equipment malfunction or communication breakdown evidence emerged, it could shift the cause away from procedural deviation.

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 documents the aircraft passing the TRP and hitting the blast barrier, indicating procedural deviation. H8 and H9 show the driver was trained and aware of the TRP, supporting that the deviation was procedural rather than environmental marking deficiency.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct evidence on environmental marking adequacy beyond TRP description; possible ambiguity in visual signal sufficiency.
